text:
ANITA WOOD: Arvind is assistant
professor of management science

and engineering at
Stanford University.

He is a member of the
Center of Work, Technology,

and Organization, the Stanford
Technology Ventures Program,

and a faculty affiliate of the
Institute for Human Centered
Artificial Intelligence.

His current research focuses
on human AI augmentation

in the workplace and its
organizational impact.

Arvind is presently working on
a new course for our Digital

Transformation
Program, and it will
be released later on this year.
Welcome, Arvind.
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Thank you.

ANITA WOOD: Let's get right
going with this little hiccup
to begin with.

Our first question in this
fireside chat is to start,

could you talk about what
are the emerging capabilities

and challenges or risks of using
generative AI in a workplace
context?
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Thank you.
Thanks, Anita.
Super excited to be here.

So there are a lot of
emerging capabilities

as we are finding out every
day that people are discovering
new use cases of generative AI.

But if we try to understand
the technology a bit more, what

is generative AI,
essentially, gen AI

is enabled by large language
models or foundational models
as they're called.

Trained on a broad set of
structured and unstructured

data and essentially data
that we find on the internet.

A lot of these labs are trained,
at least the ones we have.

They could also be trained
specifically to a vertical.

Say, there's one
now for finance.

There's going to be another
for the medical profession.

So that's going to also
change how people are going
to use these technologies.

But looking across, we could
think of two broad use cases
or two categories, if you will.
s is around generating content.

The other is around
extracting, summarizing,
or predicting information.

So these are two broad
categories, at least as of now,

on the use of generate
by the capabilities.

With respect to
generating content,

it is about anything from
generating a personalized image

or video, or
converting like a text
to a video, generating music.

So there are a lot of
applications with respect
to generating content.

And this was the part that
people were quite surprised
earlier on.

If you ask someone about AI,
and what potential capabilities

are, and where it would
affect, creative industries,

it was not the first that
came to people's mind.

People thought, OK,
maybe these could

be used in automating
routine tasks

and more like lower
level tasks that

does not involve a lot of
discretion and creativity.

But generating content is one
of the biggest capabilities
of generative AI.

The second use case,
which is about extracting,
summarizing content essentially.

So if you have a
quarterly report

or you have like a
recording of a meeting,

it's quite good at
summarizing that text.

And all the way from
reasoning about text, images,

to having some form of
chatbots, where you train

on all the customer issues
your company or product had

faced in the past, and you
could generate these automated

chatbots to essentially
accelerate the customer service
process.
So these are the two broad--

generated content, extracting,
summarizing, predicting

information are the
two broad use cases.

And within that, we are
seeing industry-specific how

these technologies are
being used, adapted.

So the legal industry,
for instance,

is one that is getting
impacted a lot because that

is dependent towards the
very text-heavy industry.

And industries,
organizations that

rely on functions,
that rely a lot on text

and images and
language more broadly.

Those are the functions,
at least as of now,
are impacted the most.
Legal industry.

The paralegals are using
generative AI a lot

to discover legal precedents
or to generate contracts, NDAs,
and stuff like that.

In advertisement agencies
and more creative industries,

graphic designers are already
using these technologies.

Copywriters to generate
a lot of options,
slogans for their clients.

So these are the
very high level.

These are some of the
emerging capabilities of AI.

And as we use it, I
think the important point

I want to emphasize
is these use cases,

nobody could find them
out ahead of time.

It is discovered in use as you
do the work, as you augment

your work with these
technologies, ChatGPT,
and DALL-E, Bard, and others.
You will discover new ones.
So those are the capabilities.
People are also using--

organizations that
are using them

to what they call as associate
listening, which is basically

like an employer
survey, employment
survey across the company.

Before, these would be
multiple choice questions,

and they will not be enough
like free-form questions

where people can
say, OK, what are

some of the issues
in the company,

and what do they want because
it's very hard to analyze them.

Imagine if it is like
a 5,000-member company.

Now it is quite easy to do that,
to summarize, find patterns

in text, or categorize
the text, and so forth.
So those are the capabilities.

With respect to the
risks, already people
have been talking about it.

The biggest risk is
what scholars they

call as the hallucination
problem, right?

So essentially,
these technologies

generate newer content
with a lot of confidence

or sounding very confidently,
but it is just made up content.

So for instance,
if I went and asked

one of these gen AI chatbots
to generate a biography of me

or anyone else, any
of my colleagues,

it gets it completely wrong
from even the basic facts.

So that's the problem,
the hallucination problem.

But if you use it for more
serious tasks, say research

tasks, it sometimes invents
content in a very confident
voice.

So there is always some
element of humans involved.

The humans need to be
there to cross-check these.
So that's the first risk.

The second is related
to copyright and IP,

especially if you are
a large company or even

a freelancer trying
to generate content.

Sometimes, there is a
risk of copyright and IP,

especially on what these
LLMs are trained on.

So it's already being an
issue, and some companies

have tried against using
these technologies to generate
new images for legal reasons.

The third risk is
related to privacy,

especially if you
try to generate code.

And so that there are
companies again that

have cutoff access to
these, like ChatGPT

and other chatbots, in
part for privacy concerns.

They don't want to
expose their own code

or use unverified code
generated by these technologies.

And the final risk is related
to numerical reasoning.

So as I mentioned,
these technologies

are trained with large
language based content.

So it's very good at
language-related tasks,
image-related tasks.

But with respect to
numerical reasoning,

even so simple sort of
arithmetic to all the way

to more advanced, like
integer programming

or advanced numerical
reasoning, it's still not there.
It's still a work in progress.

So the numerical reasoning,
I would be careful

or have some human
in the loop to verify

the results that the
technology is producing.

It is very good at
consolidating data sets

and merging data sets,
finding patterns.

But numerical reasoning,
it is still not there.
So I would caution.

There's some kind of risk
associated with that.

So these are the four
risks I can think about.

Hallucination, copyright,
privacy, numerical reasoning.
ANITA WOOD: Excellent.
That was very helpful.

And thank you for
bringing it all together.

We see a lot of news and
articles on the topic,

and it's great that you brought
it all together for everybody.
Next question.

How do we cut through
the current hype, right?

All this news and information
that's coming out.

What's the real thing
that's going to happen?
What do you think might happen?

So current hype
around AI, ChatGPT.

And how do we appreciate
the potential?

We're getting
questions about this.

How do we appreciate the
potential of generative AI
for the future of work?
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Yeah.
Great question.

So essentially, as I mentioned,
the use cases are discovered.
People are doing their work.

It's not that they could
sit and think through.
I mean, some of it they might.

But a lot of the
tasks that people do,

the potential
discovered as people
are using these technologies.

So I'd give an example
on what facilitates

this use, this creative use
of generative AI as opposed
to what hinders that.

And this is actually
based on some research

that we are currently doing
in multiple companies.

But this is a use of
generativity in a corporate law
firm.
So this is used to--

corporate law
firms, as you know,

generate a lot of contracts,
and NDAs, and documents.

It's a very
document-heavy industry.

So the paralegals
are the ones who

are responsible for
generating contracts,

and service level agreements,
and NDAs for the client, which

takes a substantial
amount of time

because each client has
specific unique capabilities.

So this organization
adopted a tool.
This is even before GPT.

There were other
vertical-specific generative AI
technologies.

This is specific to
the legal industry.

So they use this as a
test case to find out

what are the new
application areas, use
cases for this technology.

And they found the first use
case was around very simple

generating non-disclosure
agreements for clients

who are putting
together contracts

by merging multiple different
contracts in the past.
So that was the first use case.

And this law firm, two different
subdivisions the same law firm
adopted the technology.
Very similar.
Many structural dimensions.

One of the subdivisions
the paralegals

were using this
technology a lot more.

They were discovering
new use cases.

They were, for example,
discovering new use cases
around.

Or I could use this technology
not just to construct contracts

NDAs, but also to
find legal precedent

or do some background legal
research because all of that

is textual data that the
model could be trained on.

The other division people
were the paralegals

who were resisting
using the technology.

They don't want to use
it, or they we're finding
some kind of issues with it.

So we got very curious
on why is this the case.

It's the same company,
same technology.

The two subdivisions are
also more or less the same.
Similar type of paralegals too.

And that's where we
found the important role

that managers played,
the managers in these two
subdivisions.

The subdivision where there
was a lot more adoption in use,

the paralegals were
discovering new use cases

that they haven't
thought of before,

or the organization
hasn't thought of,

or even the vendor technology
vendor hasn't thought of.

In that subdivision,
the managers

were signaling
possibility of reskilling

their job to essentially
rediscovering
what a paralegal is today.
It's less about routine work.

Less about contracts, due
diligence, stuff like that.

The signaling was try to
discover new use cases that

makes your job easier
or at least the task
that you had to do.

Could you do something,
could you augment
that with these technologies?

And there was less emphasis
on consolidation or beginning

to sort of, are we going
to replace some of you?

So that rhetoric was not there
in that first subdivision

where we saw a lot of use
and a lot of experimentation.

In the division where there
was less adoption and use,

the signal that managers
sent was less so
around reskilling or upskilling.

They were not saying, OK,
we would use this technology

as an opportunity
for you to rediscover
your job or your role.

So there, the
people got-- like it

did sort of invoke the threat
frame to those paralegals.

They were not willing to
experiment with the technology
and the process.

They were not able to
discover new use cases.

Or even if they did
discover an experiment,

they were not willing
to share it widely

with their other colleagues,
other paralegals,
or their managers.

So I think the
broader point here

is the managers are going to
play a much more important role

than we think in
appreciating the potential

of the generative AI because
these gets discovered in use.
Nobody could plan ahead of time.

But having said that, the
one thing I would suggest

is if you're an
employee or a worker,

it's important to
think about, do
some form of a task inventory.
What are the tasks that you do?

There might be a job
description about you

that says these are
the tasks you do.

But then there might
be a lot more stuff
that you do beyond that.
Doing that essentially.

Then trying to
figure out what are

the tasks that
could be augmented

by these technologies, and
what are the tasks that you

want to do in the future
that you're not doing?

Something that you're
passionate about.

For example, in the
paralegals' case,

they wanted to be involved more
in the client-facing business.

They want to get involved in
the legal strategy meetings

and a lot more
like upskill tasks.

Likewise, what are the tasks
that you're not currently
doing, you want to do that?

So that sort of you could use
a generative AI to enable that.

So that's another way to think
about it doing a task inventory

and thinking about the
potential of how would you

augment your current
skills with the technology.

So these are the two
things I would say.

In order to appreciate the
potential, you have to use it,

and the managers need to sort
of be supportive of the use
and experimentation.
ANITA WOOD: Great.

I'm looking at the questions
that are coming in,

and you're already
answering a number of them.

And it's great to see everybody
thinking a little bit a step

ahead of what Arvind
is talking about.

And then hopefully, your
questions are getting answered.
One more question.

Let's see if we can squeeze
in one more question.
Let's see here.

What are some of the best
practices of human augmentation
that have worked so far?

Where was the positive,
constructive impact?
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Great.

So I would say the biggest
resistance, what I call
as the last mile problem of AI.

People who needs to
use this technology.

They are not trusting
it enough, or they

don't want to experiment, or
they experience this threat

frame that this technology
is going to replace me

or going to make my job
a lot less important.

So that is a
prominent reason why.

Or maybe the technology
is not there.

And initially, it
might get better.

But it will only get
better when people
use it, give their feedback.
So these are the barriers.

So the best practice
that I've seen work,

especially to drive more
use experimentation of AI

is to start, if you're a
manager or organization,

start with the task
that people hate to do.

So that's the task that you
could use these technologies,

ask them to find ways to
augment, automate that.

And their people would be
pretty receptive to that

because of the task that
they already had to do.

For the paralegal's
case again, it's

not a lot of one generating
contracts and NDAs given
the skills of the paralegals.
So that's one best practice.

Start with the task
that people hate to do.

The second is related
to what I mentioned.

Trying to come up with a task
inventory of what kind of stuff

people do, and map out the
dependencies between the tasks.

Especially in an
organizational context,

it is not one individual
doing all the stuff

without any
dependencies on others.

There's a lot of
coordination back and forth.

So you might be OK with
experimenting, using

these technologies, but
your colleague might not,

or your downstream
colleague might not.

So trying to map out those
dependencies earlier on,
that is also helpful.

So I call this the task
augmentation problem.

Essentially within a job,
there are multiple tasks.

Only some of them could be
augmented using AI, not all.

So trying to figure out what
they are and map all the
dependencies.

And the last one
is around the role
of managers, the best practice.

The managers started to signal
consolidation or replacement,

if that is the narrative
that they're trying to set,

then definitely, the
use of AI would reduce
the diffusion, adoption of AI.

By the people who are
supposed to experiment

with these technologies,
that would reduce.
But if they signal something--

I mean, they cannot promise that
there will be no consolidation
or no job replacement.

But at least, if they signal
that there are opportunities

to rethink, reimagine your job,
what you ideally want to do,

and potential for reskilling
and upskilling your job,

that drives people to
experiment a lot more,
share their insights.

And a lot of these insights
are shared collectively shared.

And so the capabilities
of the technologies
too are discovered in practice.

So I think these are the three
best practices I would say.
ANITA WOOD: Great.
Thank you.

Let's go ahead and take one
question from the audience.

If you were a young
professional--
you are a young professional.

For the young professionals
in our audience,

what would you
recommend they study now
with this generative AI.

And then the other
question that has popped up

a couple of times is how is
this being used in education?

How is it going to
change education?

So how do you prepare the new
professionals of the future,

and then how are you
teaching maybe differently?
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Yeah.

So I'd start with the first one
on what you should focus on.

And I cannot give
a blanket answer.

Depends on your area, what
your current interests are,
so forth.

But essentially, I would
encourage whatever your job is,

trying to see how you could
augment these technologies,

generative AI as a
part of your workflow.

So that's the one
thing I would suggest.

And there are
courses around that

on how do you use generative
AI as a part of your work.
So that's something.

Maybe like a baseline
understanding

of what these technologies are
capable of or not capable of

could also be helpful
to figure out, OK,

where you could best
use this technology,

and where this is not
a really good fit,
at least at this point in time.

So that's all that I
could say as of now.

The question on
education, we are

trying to experiment
a lot at Stanford

and rethink how we teach
our courses, but also

what kind of assignments that
we should give to students.

Should we sort of cut off
like access to ChatGPT,

or are there other
ways to rethink

how we sort of test
students, test their skills.

My perspective when I
use this in my courses

is to actually allow students
to use these technologies.

If they want to write an essay
or any form of assignment,

a presentation for that matter,
they are allowed to use it.

But then they also have to be
very reflective of the process

and training them to
write good prompts,
like teaching a course on that.

Like how do you write
good prompts, at least
a few sessions on that.

So that's going to be
an important skill.

And then owning the
content, like how do you

do cross-verification,
especially given

the hallucination problem
we've talked about?
So how do you do that?
That's another.

How do you essentially
fact-check and make

sure that what we are
producing is solid.
It's robust content.

The third is how do you
integrate all of these
to your own sort of workflow.

The students are going
to go into a workplace.

So I'm trying to structure
the assignments in the manner

that they could use
ChatGPT, and there

would be some kind of
task where you would not
be able to use it.

The questions are
framed in a manner that

involves a lot more
research, and going

to the library, or
just critical thinking.

So how do you
integrate those two?

So those are the things
that I try to teach.

And they need to also
write, reflect to one page,

like reflections on their
use of this technology,

what they learned, what
worked, what didn't work,
how did they experiment.

So I think that's
what I would suggest

for you and for
employees doing the work.

Cutting off access is not
probably a great idea.

Of course, there are, given
the privacy and other risks,

organizations might
take a different route.

But allowing people
to experiment
is the best possible route.
ANITA WOOD: Great.
Thanks.

Somebody made a comment,
and rightfully so.
Not just young professionals.
All professionals.

Those of us have been
around for some time need

to learn the new
technology, and how

we can use it to better the
experience in our environments

and for the future, and
do it in a way that's
safe and equitable.
ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Absolutely.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Can I add one quick point?
ANITA WOOD: Absolutely.

So given this a chatbot,
I think one of the issues

that I've seen with my
students but also others

is given how we are used to
doing search, using search

engines and giving
search keywords,

people are using a very
similar approach when

they use these chatbots,
ChatGPT, Bard, or any of these.
It's not a search engine.

Like if you write a prompt
as a search keyword,
it is not super effective.

So that's why I
emphasize the importance
of prompt engineering.
How do you write a good prompt?

And therefore, to understand
the technology more

would help you to
write better prompts.

So a move from a search keywords
and search queries to prompts

is going to be an important
skill for all people

to learn in respect
to young, old.
ANITA WOOD: Excellent advice.
Thank you.

We are coming to the
end of the webinar.

I want to thank everybody
who joined at the start of it

and hung in there
as we got going.

And I do want to
remind everybody

that Arvind is in the
process of developing

a new course for the Digital
Transformation Program.
It should be out this fall.
And that's what we're targeting.
Yeah.
A lot of it is focused on AI.

A lot of it on AI,
and how to write
prompts, and stuff like that.
ANITA WOOD: Awesome.

And then in the meantime,
I would recommend,

we would recommend get started
on your digital transformation
certificate now.

There are four core courses
that we recommend everybody
take as you start the program.

And then by the time
Arvind's course goes live,
you'll be ready to go.

If you have further
questions about the program

or the learning journey with the
Digital Transformation Program,

please feel free to reach
out to us via email or chat.

And with that, I want to thank
everybody for joining us today.

Arvind, thank you for joining
us today and sharing what you're

seeing not only in academia, but
also the experience that you're

doing with the work that
you're doing in industry.
So thank you, everybody.
And we wish you all a great day.
